Chopsticks are shaped pairs of equal-length sticks that have been used as the traditional ancient kitchen and eating utensils in virtually all of East Asia for over three millennia. First used by the Chinese during the Shang dynasty (1600–1046 BC), chopsticks later spread to other East Asian countries.
Chopsticks are eating utensils used in Chinese and other Asian food.

A bento is a single-portion takeout or home-packed meal common in Japanese cuisine. A traditional bento holds rice, fish or meat, with pickled or cooked vegetables, usually in a box-shaped container.

A bento box is a single-portion takeout or home-packed meal common in Japanese cuisine. A traditional bento holds rice, fish or meat, with pickled or cooked vegetables, usually in a box-shaped container. Containers range from disposable mass produced to hand crafted lacquerware.
A chopstick is a pair of small, thin, tapered sticks made from bamboo, wood, plastic or metal, used for eating food in many Asian countries.
Chopsticks are sticks made of wood or woody materials, used for eating in China, Japan, Korea and Vietnam.

Chopsticks, or 筷子 (kuàizi) in Mandarin Chinese, are a common utensil found throughout China and East Asia.

Chopsticks are formed in pairs. The first chopstick is held by the thumb and all the fingers of one hand, with the upper end resting on the crook formed by the thumb and forefinger. The second chopstick is held between the forefinger and middle finger of the hand, with the tip resting on the index finger.
